title: Energy and pd - proton moves from point P1 to P2

content.question: A proton in an electric field is initially located at Point <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> on the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. The proton is given an initial velocity in the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction, moves in a straight line along the axis, and continually slows down and comes instantaneously to rest at Point <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. What can be concluded about the electric potential at points <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: The electric potential is greater at Point <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The proton’s kinetic energy is greatest at Point <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

The electric potential is greater at Point <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The electric field does positive work on the proton as it moves from Point <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> point to Point <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

The electric potential is greater at Point <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. The proton’s kinetic energy decreases as it moves toward Point <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

The electric potential is greater at Point <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. The proton experiences a force directed toward Point <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> while it is in motion.

content.answer: The electric potential is greater at Point <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. The proton’s kinetic energy decreases as it moves toward Point <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.
